sentences.sentence: “Some days ago, a gentleman who had been looking at some houses in the Brixton Road had dropped the key of one of them in my cab.
So I had taken the chance to copy it.
By means of this I had access to one spot in this great city where I was free from interruption.
How to get Drebber to that house was the difficult problem which I had now to solve.
He walked down the road and went into one or two liquor( 酒 ) shops, staying for nearly half-an-hour in them.
When he came out, he was pretty drunk.
There was a cab just in front of me, and he called it. I followed it.
To my surprise, we found ourselves back in the Terrace where he had stayed.
I could not imagine what his intention was in returning there, but I went on and stopped my cab a hundred yards or so from the house.
He entered it, and his cab drove away.
Well, I waited for a quarter of an hour when suddenly there came a noise like people struggling inside the house.
Next moment the door was opened and two men appeared, one of whom was Drebber, and the other was a young chap( 小伙子 ).
This fellow had Drebber by the collar, and when they came to the top of the steps, he pushed him and gave a kick which sent Drebber half across the road.
‘You bastard( 混蛋 ),’ the young man cried, shaking his stick at him, ‘I’ll beat you if you insult( 侮辱 ) an honest girl again!’
So Drebber ran away down the road as fast as he could.
He ran as far as the corner, and saw my cab, he called me and jumped in.
‘Drive me to Halliday’s Private Hotel,’ said he.
When I had him inside my cab, my heart jumped so quickly with joy that I feared at this last moment my aneurysm might burst.
When I was troubled how to get him to the empty house, he solved the problem for me.
He ordered me to pull up( 靠边停 ) outside a liquor( 酒 ) shop. He went in, saying that I should wait for him.
When he came out, he was so drunk that I knew the game was in my own hands.
It was nearly one o’clock and it was rainy.
After some time, I pulled up at the house in the Brixton Road.
There was not a soul to be seen, nor a sound to be heard.
When I looked in at the window, I found Drebber was asleep.
I shook him by the arm, ‘It’s time to get out,’ I said.
‘All right, cabman( 马车夫 ),’ said he.
I suppose he thought we had come to the hotel, for he got out without another word, and followed me down the garden.
I had to walk beside him to keep him steady.
When we came to the door, I opened it, and led him into the front room.
‘It’s dark,’ said he.
‘We’ll soon have a light,’ I said, striking a match and putting it to a red candle which I had brought with me.
‘Now, Enoch Drebber,’ I continued, turning to him, and holding the light to my own face, ‘who am I?’
He gazed( 盯着 ) at me with drunken( 醉醺醺的 ) eyes for a moment, and then I saw a horror spring up in them, and his whole face shook, which showed me that he knew me.
He staggered( 蹒跚 ) back with a pale face, trembling all over.
At the sight, I leaned( 倚靠 ) my back against the door and laughed loud and long.
I never dreamed that revenge( 复仇 ) would be so sweet.
‘You dog!’ I said, ‘I have hunted you from Salt Lake City to St. Petersburg, and you have always escaped me.
Now, at last your wanderings have come to an end, for either you or I shall never see tomorrow’s sun rise.’
He shrunk still further away as I spoke, and I could see on his face that he thought I was mad. So I was, for a time.
I believed I would have had a fit of some sort if the blood had not gushed( 喷出 ) from my nose and brought me to my senses.
‘What do you think of Lucy Ferrier now?’ I cried, locking the door, and shaking the key in his face.
‘Punishment has been slow in coming, but it has come at last.’ I saw his lips tremble as I spoke.
He would have begged for his life, but he knew well that it was useless.
‘Would you murder me?’ he stammered.
‘There is no murder,’ I answered.
‘Who talks of murdering a mad dog?
What mercy had you upon my poor darling( 亲爱的 ), when you dragged her from her slaughtered( 遭屠戮的 ) father, and bore her away to your accursed( 可恶的 ) and shameless harem( 妻妾群 ).’
I had with me a box containing two pills, one deadly poisonous, one harmless, that I had obtained in America.
‘Let the high God judge between us.’ I said, ‘Choose and eat.
There is death in one and life in the other.
I will take what you leave.
Let us see if there is justice upon the earth, or if we are ruled by chance.’”

article_info.previous: Jefferson Hope坦白了自己的复仇计划。他到达伦敦后，成为一名马车夫，并暗中跟随自己的仇人。但复仇时机一直不成熟，直到有一天，Drebber与Stangerson暂时分开，于是耐心等待的猎人终于可以收网了……
article_info.share_words: There is death in one and life in the other. I will take what you leave. Let us see if there is justice upon the earth, or if we are ruled by chance.

question.cn: Jefferson为何会有一套空房子的钥匙？
question.en: How did Jefferson come to have the key to an empty house?

options.cn: 他复制了一把乘客落在车上的钥匙。
options.en: He copied the key which his passenger had dropped.

analysis: 由文中描述“Some days ago, a gentleman who had been looking at some houses in the Brixton Road had dropped the key of one of them in my cab. So I had taken the chance to copy it.”说明他的乘客将钥匙落在马车上，而他得到机会复制了一把，故选C项。

question.cn: Jefferson为何能成功地将Drebber带到房子里去？
question.en: How was Jefferson successfully able to take Drebber to the house ?

options.cn: 因为他是强迫着Drebber去那套房子。
options.en: Because he forced Drebber to the house.

options.cn: 因为Drebber喝醉了并不知道自己去了哪。
options.en: Because Drebber was too drunk to know where he went.

options.cn: 因为Drebber以前去过那套房子。
options.en: Because Drebber went to the house before.

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson准备带Drebber去准备好的房子时写到“When he came out, he was so drunk that I knew the game was in my own hands.”后面有提到Drebber下车时以为自己到了酒店。说明Drebber喝醉了，并不清楚自己去了哪，故选B项。

question.cn: Drebber在房子里看到Jefferson长相时认出他来了吗？
question.en: Did Drebber recognize Jefferson when he saw Jefferson’s face inside the house?

analysis: 文中描述在Jefferson点燃蜡烛后问Drebber是否认识他写到“He gazed at me with drunken eyes for a moment, and then I saw a horror spring up in them, and his whole face shook, which showed me that he knew me. ”说明他已经认出了Jefferson，并且十分惊恐，故选A项。

question.en: Whose blood was in the house?

analysis: 文中描述Jefferson在实行复仇计划时“I believe I would have had a fit of some sort if the blood had not gushed from my nose and brought me to my senses.”说明他因为激动流了鼻血，根据前面Holmes的推断，罪案现场的血迹也是属于凶手的。故选B项。

question.en: What did Jefferson force Drebber to do?

options.en: To take one of the pills.

analysis: 文中写到“I had with me a box containing two pills, one deadly poisonous, one harmless...There is death in one and life in the other. I will take what you leave.”说明Jefferson要让Drebber服下一片药。故选B项。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第18天
